q2.question: A PDA has a form of memory

q3.description: In this part, we will study the transition function for Pushdown Automata.
q3.question: What is the memory type the PDA has?

q5.description:
Let us take a look for PDA transition. Suppose we have $\delta(q_0, a, b) = \{(q_1, b),(q_2, ab), (q_3, \lambda)\}$
Meaning: If in state $q_0$ with $a$ the current tape symbol and $b$ the symbol on top of the stack, then pop $b$, and either
q5.question: PDAs always pop the top of the stack in every transition.

q6.description:
Let us take a look for PDA transition. Suppose we have $\delta(q_0, a, b) = \{(q_1, b),(q_2, ab), (q_3, \lambda)\}$
Meaning: If in state $q_0$ with $a$ the current tape symbol and $b$ the symbol on top of the stack, then pop $b$, and either
1. go to $q_1$ and push $b$ back to the stack
q6.question: Does the stack status changed before and after this transition?

q7.description:
Let us take a look for PDA transition. Suppose we have $\delta(q_0, a, b) = \{(q_1, b),(q_2, ab), (q_3, \lambda)\}$
Meaning: If in state $q_0$ with $a$ the current tape symbol and $b$ the symbol on top of the stack, then pop $b$, and either
1. go to $q_1$ and push $b$ back to the stack
2. got to $q_2$ and push $b$ back to the stack, then push $a$ to the stack.
q7.question: Does the stack status changed before and after this transition?

q8.description:
Let us take a look for PDA transition. Suppose we have $\delta(q_0, a, b) = \{(q_1, b),(q_2, ab), (q_3, \lambda)\}$
Meaning: If in state $q_0$ with $a$ the current tape symbol and $b$ the symbol on top of the stack, then pop $b$, and either
1. go to $q_1$ and push $b$ back to the stack
2. got to $q_2$ and push $b$ back to the stack, then push $a$ to the stack.
q8.question: What will be the top of the stack?

q9.description:
Let us take a look for PDA transition. Suppose we have $\delta(q_0, a, b) = \{(q_1, b),(q_2, ab), (q_3, \lambda)\}$
Meaning: If in state $q_0$ with $a$ the current tape symbol and $b$ the symbol on top of the stack, then pop $b$, and either
1. go to $q_1$ and push $b$ back to the stack
2. got to $q_2$ and push $b$ back to the stack, then push $a$ to the stack.
3. go to $q_3$ and do not push any thing to the stack
q9.question: Does the stack status changed before and after this transition?

q10.description:
Let us take a look for PDA transition. Suppose we have $\delta(q_0, a, b) = \{(q_1, b),(q_2, ab), (q_3, \lambda)\}$
Meaning: If in state $q_0$ with $a$ the current tape symbol and $b$ the symbol on top of the stack, then pop $b$, and either
1. go to $q_1$ and push $b$ back to the stack
2. got to $q_2$ and push $b$ back to the stack, then push $a$ to the stack.
3. go to $q_3$ and do not push any thing to the stack
q10.question: $\lambda$ in $\delta(q_0, a, b) = \{(q_3, \lambda)\}$ means do push anything to the stack

q15.description:
$\textbf{Description of a Move:}$ A move means one transition in the PDA. We describe a move in the form:
$(q_1, aw, bx) \vdash (q_2, w, yx)\quad$ iff $(q_2, y) \in \delta(q_1, a, b)$
q15.question: The change from $q_1$ to $q_2$ means that the machine moved from $q_1$ to $q_2$

q16.description:
$\textbf{Description of a Move:}$ A move means one transition in the PDA. We describe a move in the form:
$(q_1, aw, bx) \vdash (q_2, w, yx)\quad$ iff $(q_2, y) \in \delta(q_1, a, b)$
q16.question: The change from $aw$ to $w$ means that the machine read and consumed the input letter $a$

q17.description:
$\textbf{Description of a Move:}$ A move means one transition in the PDA. We describe a move in the form:
$(q_1, aw, bx) \vdash (q_2, w, yx)\quad$ iff $(q_2, y) \in \delta(q_1, a, b)$
q17.question: The change from $bx$ to $yx$ means that the machine changed
